item.description:
A matching game in which the object is to become the first player to cover all 8 states on the player's board. As the game is played, children learn many interesting and useful facts about each state, such as its shape, neighboring states, capital, nickname, state flower, important products, etc.

(From rules card with game; Milton Bradley, 1958)

A very old pair of games (1930s?) in German. Himmel und Erde is a chutes and ladders type game where players travel from Spring through Christmas by either going on the Earth or through Heaven. The description on the box cover states "Das lustige Wurfelspiel der bunten Welt im Jarheslauf".

Die Tierschau has pictures of animals with a pair of dice with different totals on a board. The players apparently work their way across the board by advancing a pawn from animal to animal along the way. There are four different sets of rules, for shorter, longer and "Doppelspiel", or "double play". The box top describes the game as "Im Spiel kreuz und quer durch das Tierreich".

Revised for 2012, Haiku: The Card Game is a system that supports 6 different rule variants in the base game. Originally, Haiku: The Card Game only played like the variant mentioned below named Haiku Hustle, which makes a good party game but experienced gamers demanded more, as did the designer.

While the core of the game, forming Haiku from the cards you collect, remains the same across all six variants, each of the six different rule sets change how you do that dramatically.

Haiku Helpers
In this collaborative version, designed for younger gamers, players are awarded points for completing lines in a Haiku both in front of them and other players. The game is over once all players have a completed Haiku in front of them.

Haiku Hustle
One of the simplest game modes, this version focuses on completing Haiku’s quickly and the winner deciding who made the best Haiku. This version works great in a party setting or as an introduction to Haiku.

Haiku Rummy
The quality, as well as quantity, of Haiku plays a major factor as an end of the game 
scoring round may determine a winner based on the quality of their best Haiku.

Haiku Auctions
Players outbid one another for a chance to recite their Haiku in front of the Emperor and gain Favor points. In the end, only the player who scored the most valuable favors will win.

Haiku Seasons
In this version, special Season Cards allow players to retain parts of their Haiku for points while a simultaneous action mechanic introduces special voting rounds.

Haiku Stackers
A quick paced abstract variant which focuses on building up or breaking down the 
Syllable Cards in a communal Haiku to maximize your point value.

In Phase, players take actions to bring powerful champions into the struggle to control the Nexus. These cards have a duality: good and evil, light and dark, etc. Cards "phase" from side to side as the game is played, creating wild swings of power that allow players to quickly shift from attack to defense and create all sorts of fun combos.

Phase was announced as a collectible card game in 2010, but will be released as a boxed set of more than three hundred cards.

This was the only game that came in AEG Black Box 2016.

Back of box, translated:

Depending on the number of players, a deck of 12-16 cards is prepared. One player draws the top card, rolls the coloured die and then reads the corresponding ANSWER on the card. Every player, including the reader, then writes down a QUESTION that could match the answer. Afterwards everybody reads their answer and points are awarded for matches.

[EN] You play a young businessman interested in invest in a growing business: the railroad. Build stations, sign mercantile contracts, buy shares, and don't forget the passengers! Relive the history expanding your rails through the cities that saw the spanish railroad grow during the 19th century.

Players must decide not only which are the proper actions to take during their actual turn, but also where actions may be favorable their next turn. The heart of the game is card drafting, so a little luck is involved. Three scoring rounds will take place through the game, all player-induced. Players who have been ready for the scoring rounds, will take the lead.

[SP] Representas a un joven emprendedor interesado en invertir en un negocio en expansión: el ferrocarril. Construye estaciones, firma contratos con compañías mercantiles, compra certificados de acción, ¡y no olvides a los pasajeros! Revive la historia extendiendo tus vías entre las ciudades que vieron crecer la red ferroviaria española durante el s. XIX.

Los jugadores deben no solo decidir cuáles son las acciones más propicias durante su turno actual, sino también prever dónde les será conveniente realizarlas en su próximo turno. El corazón del juego está en el robo de cartas, así que un poco de suerte resulta favorable. A lo largo de la partida se producirá un total de tres rondas de puntuación, inducidas por los propios jugadores. Aquellos jugadores que hayan sabido anticiparse a las rondas de puntuación resultarán aventajados.

name.value: Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa

item.description:
Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa is a non-profit, unauthorised, non-collectable card game, set within the confines of a torch-lit underground chamber holding the only mortal Gorgon, Medusa.

Consisting of two balanced 50-card decks, the game pits two players against each other in a life or death struggle. One player takes the role of the mythical hero Perseus, and his opponent assumes control of his quarry, the serpentine Medusa.

At his disposal, Perseus has four Greek soldiers to help corner and behead the, once beautiful beast, whose very expression now turns people to stone. His equipment includes treasures gifted to him by various Olympians and the Hesperides: a polished shield, adamantine sword, and a knapsack kibisis to safely contain Medusa's head.

The game has an asymmetrical design, with both decks featuring different cards and abilities. Perseus and the Sanctum of the Medusa is played without a board or map, with cards placed out by the Perseus player to simulate the Greeks' investigation of the column and statue strewn chamber. Gameplay is quick and bloodthirsty with Greeks petrified, or slain by bowshot and acid pool frequently.

Drawn partially from Greek myth, the game is inspired hugely by the 1981 film Clash of the Titans.

The game's lineage can be traced back to Magic: The Gathering, BattleTech CCG, and Iliad.

item.description:
In this twist on the classic word game, Scrabble, players use their seven drawn letter-tiles to form words on the gameboard. The twist is that now, proper names such as cities or celebrity names will now be allowed. Other twists include "playing words backwards or playing words unconnected to others on the board," Mattel said. The game is a limited edition and will not replace the original Scrabble.

Just like regular Scrabble, each word laid out earns points based on the commonality of the letters used, with certain board spaces giving bonuses. But a word can only be played if it uses at least one already-played tile or adds to an already-played word. This leads to slightly tactical play, as potential words are rejected because they would give an opponent too much access to the better bonus spaces.

Not all precise details are known yet as Scrabble Trickster is due out in July in the U.K. only.

Publisher Blurb:
Learn about hiking the Appalachian Trail as you play the Trail Magic game. Fun and fast moving play is created by a combination of multiple choice trivia questions, chance, food rations and questions about your trail mates. The game is designed for groups of 2 or more and ages 10 and up.

Start at either Springer Mountain in Georgia, the southern end of the trail or at Mt. Katahdin in Maine at the northern end. Pick up rations at food stops, cross your fingers that the bears don't eat your food, and answer trivia questions as you try to make your way to the other end of the trail.

The game board shows many of the important landmarks and towns along the trail as well as watercolor illustrations of a few sites. 140 trivia cards as well as 60 environmental hazard & hiking community cards are included.

A portion of proceeds from the sale of Trail Magic benefits the Appalachian Trail Conference, which maintains the Appalachian Trail.

item.description:
Aliens of many different races have come together, some in war, others in negotiations.

In this game you will be encountering random players and either fighting to take them over or negotiating and coexisting. The random 5 aliens selected each game will vary the game play and manipulate the game through the various powers. See if you can come out in the lead conquering or negotiating to establish 5 colonies first.

This game uses a locking die mechanic that is seen in many other express games and emphasizes push your luck mechanics. You may be forced to negotiate even when it isn't in your best interest, or you might try for a higher number only to lose the die from the X result.

A game with numbers for small children. Every player gets the same number cards (they depict every number between 1 and 10 twice), and a goal number between 1 and 20 is turned up. The first player who can make this number using his/her number cards, addition and subtraction can discard those cards. Then another goal number is turned up. The winner is the first player who discards all the cards.

In Guckloch, the players have to recognize pictures through a little hole in a board. If they can name the object they see just partly, they can add it to her collection. The player who has collected a certain combination of pictures first is the winner.

contents:
4 wooden collection boards with 6 pictures each
24 wooden boards with a picture
3 wooden boards with holes to look through

Welcome to the world of Scoreboard Baseball !
Scoreboard Baseball is a full stat quick play baseball game that can be played in around 10-12 minutes from out of the box to stat completion. There are no lineups to decide upon and no score sheets to fill out yet the game unfolds inning by inning with a key player and action being revealed along the way. While it can be used to add on to existing full play baseball games, such as Inside Pitch Baseball, it can also hold its own as a season replay game.

Each team is represented by a single chart that shows all of the possible players and how they effect scoring in an inning when called upon to deliver as a key player. It could be the 3rd string catcher that comes through or maybe your backup shortstop. One roll per inning gets you all the action plus all the pitchers stats for that inning.

All hitters are rated for, basically, runs created. This is how runs can be scored during an inning. They also have ratings for HR, 3B, 2B, SB and hits in general. How often a hitter is called upon is based on how many plate appearances he had during the season being replayed. The bigger the hit type, a HR beats a single, the better chance to have that big inning. How many runs a team scored in an inning during the year is recreated with Scoreboard as each team has its own scoring chart.

Pitchers are rated on H, K and BBs. They also have ratings which can cause runs to score in an inning or block potential runs from scoring. The pitchers' stay in the game relies upon how many hits, runs and walks he gives up in his stint. Deciding who pitches doesn't slow the game down as pitchers have start and relief ranges that you can use to "coach" the team.

Relievers are not left out of the mix as all their appearances and stats can be tracked as well. When to bring in a certain reliever is also covered with 7 different scoring/inning breakdowns that are based upon actual year appearances. Your middle guys will come in at the proper times and be effective (non-effective) just like the year the charts recreate.

While most stats are gathered during the game some loose ends must be accounted for at games' end. These are handled with each player given ranges to fill in those RBI and hit stats so that the score sheet comes out even.

You don't just roll for a final score in Scoreboard but you get the ebb and flow of the game broken down per inning. Sometimes your less than stellar players will need to come through in a pinch recreating the excitement of a play-by-play game just done quicker. By the end of the game, you will have these stats for the players as well as see when and how they happened in the game.

Pitchers: W, L, SV, IP, H, R, ER, K, BB

Hitters: H, 2B, 3B, HR, SB, RBI

After a series or two from a team, multipliers are given to each player to show how many AB he would have based on the number of games his team has played. This can be used to get you batting average leaders, etc... for your league.

Get on the Board with Scoreboard Baseball !

A Game for Two Players

The object of the game is to try to place four counters of the same colour in a row. Players take turns to throw the four dice (2 yellow, 2 white), and put a counter on a square on the board according to the dice score, with yellow dice counting on the horizontal axis, and white dice on the vertical axis.

The game art is tennis based, but there is no real tie in with tennis in the game itself.

This is a precis of the rules from the rule book.

item.description:
The game is played on four trays, each tray having four by four holes where marbles can be placed. The trays are placed side by side on the board and each player starts the game with 12 marbles. On each players turn he can place one of his marbles on any tray as he chooses and thus trying to make four in a row (or a Q4 as it's called in the game rules). The Q4 can be on a single tray or spanning all the trays (that is, three dimensional).

After a player has played all his marbles he can start to move them around (on the same tray or between trays). After placing a marble he can claim a Q4. If the Q4 is on a single tray it should be fairly obvious whether it's a Q4 or not. If the Q4 spans all the trays, they must be stacked (the leftmost being on the bottom, the rightmost on the top) and then it can be checked whether the claim for a Q4 is true or not.

The first one to make a Q4 wins the game.

Similar to:

 3D Tic Tac Toe - which is played on 3x3x3 grid
 Four Letter Words - though with words
 Qubic - which is also played, with placement only, on 4x4x4 grid but with 32 markers for each player
 Tetrano - which is the same game represented on a 4x4 board.
 Qubic - which has a version for 3 players also
 Score Four - 4x4 grid of pegs that are filled from the bottom up

Polis: Fight for the Hegemony is a two-player civ-lite game set in the beginning of the conflict between the two major poleis of the 5th century B.C: Athens and the Delian League against Sparta and the Peloponnesian League. The winner will be the Empire with more population and prestige at the end of the game.

With a growing empire, feeding your people is the main goal. Wheat was scarce in Greece, so both players must secure other goods supply and the route to five markets in order to trade them for wheat. Each territory may give you different amount of wood, metal, wine, olive oil, silver and some wheat; these two last ones are hard to get but precious. It’s up to you if you want to get more of only one good or less from several of them. Every turn you get goods from a territory you must have some population there (supporting your Empire) but in the end they also have to be fed.

Fighting for the control of the territories and the sieges of the polis will be the job of your hoplites, your triremes will struggle to secure the routes to Egypt, Persia...so you can trade with them when the price is low, and a good use of your Diplomatic may convince a Polis to join your League easily.

A Polis may be your ally, but they are very proud of their independence, so you will have to create some Projects (statues, temples, artists, philosophers, games...) in order to gain Prestige which is needed for all your military manoeuvres.

item.description:
100 Points Hold'em is a simple, casual card game in the 100 Points line of games that uses 100 Points cards.

Like Texas Hold'em? Want to try something different and maybe a little simpler? Then try 100 Points Hold'em!

In 100 Points Hold'em players are dealt 2 cards face-down. The Dealer then plays 2 cards (one at a time) face-up while players bet token to stay in the game. Using the 2 cards dealt to them face down and the 2 shared cards dealt face-up on the table, players see who has the best hand. The player closest to 100 points in their hand without going over wins the round. The game ends when only one player has 3 tokens or more.

For 2 to 5 players. Simple. Casual. Fun. 100 Points Hold'em

(Publisher description)

100 Points Prediction is a simple, casual card game in the 100 Points line of games that uses 100 Points cards.

In 100 Points Prediction each player rolls a 6-sided die and draws a number of cards equal to their roll. Each player then guesses as to what the total number of points are of all the cards in all the players' hands. One by one players reveal their cards and everyone finds out the the total number of points. The player who guessed the closest without going over wins. The losing players put their cards in their discard pile. The last player with cards in their deck wins.

The game can be played with 2 or more players.

Each player needs their own set of 100 Points cards and a 6-sided die to play the game. 
(Publisher description)

You have just finished your evil doctorate. Now it's time for you to return to a castle on the outskirts of the town where you grew up, to begin your tyranny in the name of revenge. Every bully that gave you a wedgie in school and every cutie who laughed at your advances will feel the wrath of the monster you are about to create...

Your goal in Good Help is to create the best monster that you can, then unleash it on the public – but don't take too long as the first player to have his monster destroy five buildings in town wins. Alternatively, you can set your monster on those of the other players, and if you have the last monster standing, you win.

To assist you in your goal – and to preserve your reputation in town – you'll hire assistants, then send them out to collect body parts, buy supplies and earn money. Your assistants can confront those of other doctors to try to steal away the gold, supplies or limbs they carry. Each assistant has at least one vice, however, and when moving about town they might be lured away by the prospect of beer, jewelry, dresses or sausage, selling or dropping everything they have to get their fix. Good help is indeed hard to find!

item.description:
Portal is a two-player abstract game played on a hex board where player's attempt to capture each others pieces. Each player has four different sized units that can move different amounts of spaces on a turn (1-4). Pieces are allowed free movement but may not move through a space they have already occupied that turn or move through another piece. Pieces can only capture in a straight line of hexes equal to their movement amount and may jump other pieces when capturing.

A key aspect to Portal is the turn structure. On alternating turns players will make one and two movements. That is, on turn 1, P1 will move once and P2 twice. On turn 2, P1 moves twice and P2 moves once and so on.

A portal board consists of three seperate types of "special" hexes.

The middle hex is the Portal. If you begin your turn with a piece in the portal you may move it to any open open, non-special space on the board and then make your movement(s) for that turn.

The spaces surrounding the portal are weakened. A piece in those spaces may not make a capturing move, except a "1" may capture into the portal only.

The red corner spaces are protected. A piece in that space cannot be captured, however, it must be moved out of that space on the player's next turn or it is removed from the board.

The game ends when one player has one or fewer pieces remaining on the board. Each remaining piece scores points equal to its movement value. The player with the higher score wins.

Portal is currently entered in the nestorgames continuous abstract contest as well as the 1,000 Year Design Challenge.

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/48043/item/1260124#item1260124

www.thousandyeargame.com

A promotional game by International Team commissioned by some tobacco companies (Philip Morris, etc.) (the game was recommended for ages 12+ (!)). Every player is a different kind of smoker, moving along the game board the players must find out what type of smoker the other players are.

Want to make Mama proud? Become My Son the Doctor. Let Mama impress her friends. Become My Daughter the Movie Star. Maybe you'd rather have money and influence. Become My Son the Tycoon. How about...would you like to rule the world? Become My Son the Politician. All it takes is a little luck...a little concentration and knowing when to keep your mouth shut!

(From front page of the rules.)

Drawing on traditional Jewish humor, this game encourages players to aspire to their Mama's dreams of becoming somebody. Players begin at home with Mama and through the course of the game, pick up Odd Jobs and Tools of the Trade. Once the player gets to their target profession after acquiring 4 Good Tools for that Trade, they win!

Movement on the board is via dice, one specifically for each dimension, with the player choosing the direction. Landing on a free Odd Job gains the player both a random Odd Job card and a random Tool from a profession of their choice. If a player lands on someone else's Odd Job and they get to steal a Tool. Being lazy will cause a player to lose a turn, and sometimes it's best just to Go Home to Mama. However, if a player can catch a Lucky Break, then end up on a square of their choice, which is the best way to land a profession!

The mechanics are simple, but remembering who has what can be more difficult as cards are constantly being exchanged.

item.description:
In Tall Towers each player represents a carpenter during the Medieval Age who has been tasked with building a city tower for the Prince. Each player must build a tower taller and more efficiently than the other players. Everyone grabs one of the 6 foundation boards, each with a unique build queue that you are trying to complete during the frantic trading sessions.
After everyone has chosen a foundation board, the game can begin. There are 2 phases repeated throughout the game. The first phase is the Trading/Resource Gathering Phase. Everyone starts with the same deck of 40 Cards, but you will not be using your own cards to build your Tall Tower. Instead the trading/resource gathering is done through an interesting real-time blind trading mechanic. It is a quick thinking and chaotic trading session quite similar to games such as Pit, or Set. Everyone is trading simultaneously, so act fast to get the cards you need, and bluff your opponents into taking the bad cards from your hand. 
The second phase is the Build Phase, where you use the cards you received in the previous phase to build your Tall Tower. Of course it is not as easy as it sounds. You must play the cards in the order you received them, you cannot rearrange your hand. Some cards are good and will help you finish up the next floor of your Tower, or they could be bad and send cracks through a few of the stones you gathered during the Resource Phase.
The Players go through 8 Rounds (of 5 cards each) alternating between these 2 phases, and the one with the Tallest Tower wins. There is lots of chaos during trading, lots of speculation between players as they try to talk each other into taking their cards, and lots of fun as you flip over your resources and see how good you did or how bad you crumbled.

name.value: The Price Is Right Game: DVD Edition

item.description:
From the back of the box: The DVD Version of the Price is Right enables players to "Come on Down" and be a part of all the action and excitement of a real TV show contestant. Try your hand at Plinko, or Cliffhangers, and live the thrill of spinning the big wheel in the Showcase Showdown.

This game is very similar to The Price Is Right but instead of requiring a player to play the host, the DVD contains the emceeing of Todd Newton and announcer work by various Price announcers, most prominently then-current announcer Rich Fields. It also supports a larger number of players.

link.value: TV Series: The Price is Right

item.description:
(from back of box)
"Get SUPERCHARGED with Lightning McQueen and his pals as they prepare to compete with cars from around the world in the Radiator Springs Supercharged International Grand Prix! The neon's sizzling, the asphalt's hot, and Lightning's pals are sporting slick new paint jobs as they gear up for the big race. Put your pedal to the metal and steer right to the hottest spot in racing - Radiator Springs. Play this supercharged spinner Bingo with Lightning McQueen and his pals, all your favorite Cars characters!"

This is a children's bingo game with a Cars theme. Each player receives a bingo card with a 5x5 grid of Cars characters (Ramone, Doc Hudson, Guido, Lightning McQueen, Mater, Sally, Luigi) with different colored backdrops (Red, Green, Yellow, Blue, Purple). A spinner is used to call spaces. For example: If the spinner arrow points to the color blue and Mater's face, "Blue Mater" is called out. Any player with a Blue Mater picture on their card would cover it with a chip. The first player to cover 5 characters in a row with chips wins.

User Summary...

Created as a follow-up to the Starbattles tactical space combat game, Starbattles (The Card Game) is described in its rulebook as "a beginner level card game of tactical space combat. It is a fast paced card game where all the action is in front of you and in your hand."

To date, only simply produced play-test versions of this game have been documented. It is unknown whether or not this game ever made it into full production.

Components:
- 1 Rules Folder (6 pages on continuous paper)
- 54 Ship Cards (all cards for this game are printed on sheets for players to cut out)
- 1 Set of Hit/Destroyed Counters (the sheet devoted to last minute changes indicates that these are not included)
- 6 Play Sheets 
- 6 Player Order Cards
- 114 Action Cards
- (a six-sided die is required, but not included)

Notes on play:
Each player has a Play Sheet where ship status and damaged is tracked. Essentially, the Play Sheet represents a player's home base... their ships (as represented on Ship Cards) are placed on areas on the Play Sheet that show the ship's position relative to their base. Players score victory points by finishing off other player's ships. The game ends and victory points are totaled when only one player has active ships left.

A light illustrated cardgame, where the first player with only three cards in his hands (1 place, 1 dress and 1 vehicle) is the winner. Every player starts with 10 cards and on their turn play cards that matches the previous card. Special cards (ban, +3, miss your turn etc.) make it harder for your opponents.

Text on back of the box:
"By taking the cable car, reach the moon dressed in armour. It's possible! But avoid the pitfalls! You have to be sharp to arrive first."

item.description:
(from the Web Site)Untold Battle™ is a fast-paced, exciting way for players to duke it out with custom built creatures and parties. Showcasing the many Battle Factions of the Untold universe, Untold Battle was created for two players to choose two opposing factions and fight with tooth, bullet, tentacle and spell until only one side remains. But Battle players are not limited - they can use all of the Untold cards to change and make their units unique, or even create their own character, just as if they were going to play the roleplaying game. And Battle doesn't need to be two sided, the rules work for one-on-one, one-on-many, or many-on-many. Untold Battle Rules provide a brutal, bloody, and hard-hitting game that packs a punch!
The Battle Factions

Untold offers limitless possibilities for worlds and adventures. And on every world there are nations, corporations, shadow organizations, alien marauders, and so forth; we collectively call these Factions. We've built all the unique creatures, minions, soldiers, and things that go bump in the night and put them together in Battle Faction packs, so you can pick your favorites or mix and match to do Battle. Untold Battle offers an arena for all the forces of your imagination to duke it out. Now you can pit zombies against soldiers, or tentacled demons against steam punk robots. Or you can help shape the destiny of one of the Untold worlds: will the brave forces of the North American Union overcome the twisted Flux Horrors? Or you can help reshape the face of Europe as the Churl Confederation advances on the new knights of Novus Europa!
The Untold Rules

Untold Battle utilizes Untold Minion Cards because they are quick to use. Minions are one card, instead of a number of cards, that represent a single character, and that is important when your Battle has a large number of forces. And Minions still offer the limitless customization of Untold Powers through Swapping.

Once players choose their Factions and/or characters, Battle is as simple as lining up the cards on the table across from each other and taking turns between their minions. Battle utilizes Untold's simple and quick combat mechanics (see our Online Primer for more, or just refer to back of the handy insert that comes with every Battle Faction pack), and all the rules you need for the minions are on the cards!

Expat-Abenteuer is designed to prepare players, particularly families with children, for moving abroad. There are several expansions for specific countries.

The players roll and move along a track. The goal is to earn "expat points". The points are awarded by cards, other cards send the players forward or back. The cards can be kept for future use, but when certain points on the track are reached, the players have to discard them and receive negative points for them. 
Whenever a player draws a card, another player can also force one of his/her cards on him/her, making the "trip" less predictable. 
The first player to reach the end of the track gets some bonus points. The player with most points is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

An Axis & Allies like strategy game reliving the dramatic events of operation Market-Garden in September 1944. A large narrow mapboard represents the area from Eindhoven by Nijmegen to Arnhem. Units are plastic pieces representing infantry, tanks and artillery; 13 important plastic bridges are included. Almost every bridge is a stepping-stone to success. And every bridge can be blown.

The purpose of the game is to reach Arnhem and make contact with the British paras. The time frame is restricted and if the Allied player doesn't reach Arnhem on time, the paras are doomed and an easy target for the German elite forces!

The RULES are short and simple: the game focusses on strategy, and nothing else.

The game map has all the necessary information needed to play the game. Once you've read the rules once, there's no need to look up things anymore. (almost) Every bit of information is on the map.
No looking up hit probabilities, defense factors, or attack factors in rows and columns. No measuring with rulers. Just roll the dice.

Combat is resolved with the use of ten-sided color coded dice: so there's some luck involved, but a reasonable level.

Good tactics require the use of an optimal mix of units to get the job done.
Each kind of unit has its specific strength and weakness, depending on the battleground. Players should choose wisely which units to use where and when.
In this game the players don't get to choose the casualties themselves: a roll with the dice reveals the distribution of the hits. The FOG OF WAR is simulated by distributing the hits at random. In this way you are never totally in control: you plan your strategies, you work out plans, you anticipate as much as you can, but the outcome is never, ever perfect. With "Arnhem'44" both players get a much more 'realistic' game experience playing this game.

name.value: Dragons: Sauvez le trésor des dragons!

item.description:
Dragons: Wettflug zur Dracheninsel ("Dragons: Race to Dragon i=Isle") is a game based on Dreamworks' How to Train Your Dragon 2. In the game, the dragon riders attempt to reach the Dragon Isle, while the dragon Screaming Death tries to prevent them from doing so.

At the beginning of each game, the board is created by lining up island tiles, starting with Viking Island (start) and ending with Dragon Isle (finish). The islands between start and finish come in four different colors.

The game is played in rounds. Each round, one player plays Screaming Death, while the others play a dragon rider. Each dragon rider has a hand with colored island cards. Each turn, each dragon rider selects one of these cards. At the same time, Screaming Death selects one color of islands to attack. Then, everybody reveals their cards. Each dragon rider that has selected the color that is being attacked by Screaming Death cannot move; the others move to the next island of their chosen color.

The round ends when two dragon riders have reached Dragon Isle, or when the dragon riders can no longer move because the deck of island cards has run out. The first dragon rider to reach Dragon Isle gains two coins; the second rider gains one coin. If no dragon rider reaches Dragon Isle, Screaming Death gains three coins. If only one rider reaches Dragon Isle, Screaming Death gains one coin.

The game continues with a new round, until each player has played Screaming Death once. Then, the player who has collected the most coins wins.

Spooky, an earlier version of this game, had the players as ghosts moving through a castle, with each player taking a turn as Merlin to try to stop the ghosts.

In the Demise of Dr. Frankenstein you roll a number of dice, 6 for 2 players, 8 for 3 or 4 players, then those dice are placed on different action options based on the numbers rolled. The number one lets a player influence Igor, number two lets a player take body parts from the graveyard and so on. That allows players to influence different village members and accomplish different tasks on their way to building a Frankenstein Monster. After players use the clinician to study, the trader to get goods, bribe officers to look the other way as they construct different contraptions, and visit the curator, the villagers reach their anger boiling point and put an end to it all by buring down the doctors' efforts. Victory points are scored and then it's on to the next round until all players have had a chance to go first one time.

item.description:
Fast-paced calculation game for 1 to 8 players. On their turn, player throws 14 special 6-sided dice with numbers ranging from 1 to 15. Then player tries to place them in a grid of four rows, so that all rows show correct calculations. Correct calculations score points. Time for placement is limited with a hourglass.

The grid looks like this: (X = places for dice).
X + X = X
X - X = X
X * X = X +- X
X / X = X +- X

Similar to Minut spelet which is for 2 players only.

Enter the world of Wonderland and help Alice reach the Frabjous Day! You must navigate through Wonderland in order to encounter the Mad Hatter, the Cheshire Cat, the White Rabbit and the Red Queen, but watch out! This path moves!

Featuring four separate boards that make up one larger game board, Alice in Wonderland is a shifting, madcap world. Who will be the first to reach the Frabjous Day?

Players take turns moving through different sections of Wonderland (The Rabbit Hole, the Forest, the Tea Party and the Red Queen's Castle) collecting Drink Me cards. The Drink Me cards are used in each section to collect a favor from each of the characters that reside in that section of Wonderland (the White Rabbit, the Cheshire Cat, the Mad Hatter and the Red Queen, respectively).

Once a player has collected favors from all four characters, they may move to the Frabjous Day. The first player to reach the Frabjous Day wins!

item.description:
In Mentis, your goal is to capture the opponent's king. Each player's king is fragile, unable to move from his hill on the side of the 7x7 board, but he defends that hill by sending out forces of Spears, Trenchmen and Nobles to fight across the board. Each turn, you either deploy, move or capture:


 Deploy — Place 1-3 pieces in a stack orthogonally adjacent to your king's hill in a square not adjacent to an opponent's piece. You can place on an empty square or one holding your pieces, but you can't create a stack more than three pieces high.
 Move — Move pieces orthogonally 1-3 spaces depending on the type of piece on top of the stack. You can drop off and pick up pieces as you move as long as you obey the three piece limit.
 Capture — Use the top piece of your stack to capture an opponent's piece, but only if that piece is exactly the right distance (1-3 spaces) from the capturing piece and isn't of a type immune to attack from the capturing piece.

item.description:
Flying Officer Stumpy Prangsworthy’s handlebar moustache streamed behind him in the 280mph wind as he craned his head round trying to locate where Von Strudels Focke Wulf 190 A8 had gone to. Deep within the cloud, the spineless Boche had shown his true colours and escaped Stumpys righteous justice. The growling Merlin engine sang a new song as he side-slipped his trusty Supermarine Spitfire down towards the now helpless Dornier 17.
 The Dornier was almost at the target and in scant moments would land at the brewery and snatch No14 Squadrons Claret from under their noses. Well Stumpy would see about that. He loosed the safety off of his eight .303’s and aimed at the Dorniers port engine.
 Suddenly from behind screaming out of a wingunder manoeuvre the FW 190 appeared in Stumpys vanity mirror, its cannons sparkling motes of fire. A shell smashed into the Spits wing and tore the aileron. “Blast you, Von Strudel “yelled Stumpy as he realised that he had been sold a duffer and was gone for a burton. Only one trick could save him. Feathering his Kites prop, he hit the airbrakes and was rewarded with the bright green FW 190 flashing under him. Dropping the nose Stumpy let rip a corking burst which caught the Jerry a treat. Flames poured from the FW 190’s engine and Von Strudel Hit the Silk. 
Von Strudel shook his fist as Stumpy flashed past. “Verdammt Englander! Finish me now! The shame is too great!”
“Not a chance old pip,” grinned Stumpy; “A Englishman flies by the rules of the game, and potting a Chap on his chute is defiantly not playing the game.”
So what is playing the game? You are about to find out!

Blazing Skies is a Tactical WW2 Flight combat game. Each player takes control of a WW2 aircraft and battles his/her opponents in fast paced duels to the death. The roar of engines, the rattle of dice , the contrails streaming from wingtips and the chugging down of pints of claret. Its all here in Blazing Skies.

45 full colour pages of rules, background, templates, charts, diagrams and quick reference sheets
Six exciting scenarios and one boring one.
A physics model that simulates the effects of gravity, engine power, high energy manouvers.
A campaign game that rewards skillful pilots
Take offs!
Landings!
Prangings!
Collisions!
Gongs!
Random Events!
A huge list of literally hundreds of WW2 and interwar aircraft.Evrything from the mundane to the mad with more on the way!
Support via email and forums
Clouds
Flack
Bombing
Pilots personal skill
Idiosyncratic Aircraft that behave like their real life counterparts! Except in model form! if its a avro Manchester, it will handle like slop and struggle at altitude, its engines will also overheat!
Updates to new kites and scenarios as and when I get round to doing em.
This is a truely epic set of WW2 rules and is set to become the benchmark for Air Combat games. it is designed for 1/144 or 1/72 scale aircraft and a dogfight is easily playable in 30 mins. Multiplane fights are easily fought to a conclusion in a hour.

The Luftwaffe trained its best pilots in WW2 using these rules.*

The rules are easy to pick up and play and have plenty of examples. in fact, you start off at RAF Debden where the Sq ldr will take you through your first flight.


 Not actually true


Dust off your old airfix kits or FOW 1/144 planes and put in an order to Topgunmarketing for some flightstands.

Chocks Away!

Crazy Yatzy is Yahtzee with all the catagories you have longed for. Built upon the scandinavian version of Yahtzee Crazy Yatzy includes, among others: Almost a pair, Almost three of a kind, Another chance, yet another chance and CRAZY. The last one is thrown with the eyes closed, and then you have to either trust, or distrust which dice your fellow players tell you to reroll.

Note that Alga also published another Yahtzee variant under the name Crazy Yatzy which included dexterity elements, nonsensically named categories and so on.

[From the back cover]

Basic things you need to understand and then you can play Checkers with a partner.

Partners: face each other and each player plays in turn in a clockwise direction.

All checker pieces: move or jump according to the Standard Rules of Checkers

...Except...


 each single checker changes its forward direction only once...when it moves or lands in or beyond a square with double lines. NOW, the checker piece is directed to its nearest opponent..."very easy" to follow on the game board.



 Double lines have no meaning to KINGS.


Object of the game:
Each player will try to jump and capture all of his two opponents' pieces.

To Win:
All opponents' pieces must be captured or blocked. A blocked checker piece cannot move. Otherwise, the game is a DRAW.

Cutthroat (2, 3 or 4 players): each player plays independently.

The Rock 'n' Roll Trivia Game

The board for this music trivia game represents an old-fashioned LP record. Players start at the outer rim of the 'album" and move to the center just like a phonograph needle.

Questions include categories like Artists, Titles, and Off The Record which covers other areas of the music industry. This game is designed for 2 to 6 players and follows a typical trivia game format... a contestant reaches the final space and must answer a tough question to win.

Includes the LP record style board, 6 LP tokens, a die, cards, rules, and a storage insert.

(c)1984 Universal Distributors

Made in Canada

The game simulates the battle to retake the island of Iwo Jima from the Japanese in February 1945. The battle was the hardest ever fought by the marines or the Japanese for such a small place. The island though was critical to take from the US standpoint as an emergency landing area for the Marianas based B29's. Rules are based on the 7 Battlefield Operating Systems:
Command and Control
Intelligence
Fire Support
Air Defense
Combat Service Support
Mobility and Survivability
Maneuver

From the back of the box...

Five Complete Simulation Games

At last Simulations Publications has an integrated Pre-Seventeenth Century Tactical Game Systems (PRESTAGS) for simulation of all military systems prior to the predominance of fire weapons.

The game system used in this series is based on the highly-regarded Musket & Pike system (although many modifications and special rules were devised to demonstrate the differences between historical periods.) All the games are compatible -- and they can be used to trace the evolution of tactics over the course of history from 3000 B.C. to 1550 A.D. Each game in the series covers a segment of the period, and presents the tactical situations faced by leaders of the great battles of the period.

User Notes:
The games included in the somewhat hard to find PRESTAGS Master-Pack are: Chariot, Legion, Spartan, Viking, & Yeoman. Each game in the pack comes with 400 counters, so the full set contains a whopping 2000 counters. The set is comprised of not one, but two SPI flat packs, along with maps and rules for each game, and with PRESTAGS rules that cover the full series. All the sets are compatible, or as the back of the box states, "Because the strength values of the the units were all derived from the same base, units from one game are entirely compatible with another."

Berlin 1945 (Fall of the Reichstag) is a two-person game that recreates the Battle of Berlin April 24 - May 2 1945, the last great battle and the end of World War II. One player represents the German army and the other the Soviet army. The final chapter in the destruction of Third Reich began on April when Stalin unleashed the brutal power of 20 armies, 6,300 tanks and 8,500 aircraft with the objective of crushing German resistance and capturing Berlin. The depleted German forces put up a stiff defense, initially repelling the attacking Russians, but ultimately succumbing to overwhelming force. The Soviet army surrounded the city slowly tightening its stranglehold on the remaining defenders. Fighting street-to-street and house-to-house, Russian troops blasted their way towards the city's center.
Game’s Goal
The Soviet army must reach the Reichstag and defeat the defending German troops at that area by outnumbering them by at least 2 to 1. The German player must defend the city and prevent the arriving Soviet troops from taking over the Reichstag (German Headquarters).

Game contents

-A Board with a map of Berlin divided into 23 numbered zones (called districts) and Ground Zero in the center, composed of an additional 5 districts. 
-64 counters –[(One counter represents a regiment or division (3,000 to 10,000 men)]: 
34 red, representing the Soviet invading forces (Russians, Ukrainians, Poles, etc.), 
22 grey and 5 black (Waffen SS), representing the combined troops of Germans.
2 counters representing barricades (only in play on board if the German player draws event card “barricades”).
1 colorless marker cube.
-50 event cards. 25 for Germans and 25 for Soviets

source: game designer

Berlín 1945 (La caída del Reichstag) es un juego para dos personas que recrea la batalla de Berlín 24 abril-2 mayo de 1945, la última gran batalla y el fin de la Segunda Guerra Mundial. 
Un jugador representa al ejército alemán y otro al ejército soviético.

Objetivo del juego
El ejército soviético debe alcanzar y derrotar a las tropas alemanas y el cuartel general situado en la zona del Reichstag. El jugador alemán debe defender la ciudad e impedir que las tropas soviéticas lleguen a la zona central y tomen el Reichstag. El juego dura 12 turnos (del 21 de abril al 2 de mayo).

Componentes del juego
Consta de los siguientes componentes:
-Un tablero con el mapa de Berlín dividido en 23 zonas numeradas (distritos).
-64 fichas: 
34 rojas, que representan las tropas invasoras soviéticas (rusos, ucranianos, polacos, etc.), 
22 grises y 5 negras ( Waffen SS), que representan a las tropas combinadas alemanas. 
2 azules que representan barricadas (sólo entran en juego si sale la carta alemana barricadas).
1 un cubo que se usa de marcador de turno. 
50 cartas de eventos. 25 alemanas y 25 soviéticas

(from ADG's website:)

Flaps, Throttle, Chocks Away! The glamour, mystique and courage of the battle of Britain is brought to life in this elegant design of that great campaign that marked the end of the beginning of the greatest Conflict in History. Take command of the German or Commonwealth air fleets as you battle it out over the skies of London and England desperately trying to save your country from destruction from the sky.

Battle for Britain is a stand alone boxed game that is fast paced, easy to learn but tough to master game covering the entire air war over Britain during those critical months of August and September 1940 when the world held its breath as to the outcome. Containing a unique hidden movement system, a wide variety of units and a rich array of strategic detail, Battle for Britain gives you everything you need to re-fight the greatest air battle in history. Can Germany knock out England’s air defences preparatory to an invasion of the plucky little island or can England repel the Nazi sky hordes and begin preparing for the time when she can return democracy to Europe? Now as Air Chief Marshal Hugh Dowding or Generalfeldsmarschall Hermann Goering you can find out.

Battle for Britain contains:
• 1 large map (1168mm x 820mm) (46" x 32")
• 400 full colour counters

item.description:
(from ADG's website:)

Australian Design Group is pleased to announce our latest project, World in Flames - The Master Edition, the definitive boardgame of World War II.

Since 1999 Rüdiger Rinscheidt has been working on the Master Edition’s design and development. It is a complete conflict simulation about the Second World War for 2-5 players on divisional scale. This boardgame does not replace World in Flames - The Final Edition but supplements it in fine detail for the afficionado of World War II history.

While based on Australian Design Group's award winning game World in Flames, the Master edition has many new features including:
• monthly turns;
• divisional scale;
• reserve movement;
• crack units for every major power (like Guard Banner Armies);
• complete new land combat system including battle points (like surprise points within naval battles), simultaneous attack/defence dice rolls and reserve movement after combat (both attacker and defender);
• and much much more (see fuller description below).

WiF Master edition is a complete boxed game that comes in two versions, the standard game played using the 5 World in Flames maps (i.e. can be played within the same space as the current game) and the deluxe version which includes 6 large maps (and the US minimap) providing far greater scope for sweeping operational manoeuvres across the globe.

The rules are the same length as the current rule set and you can download the draft version at www.gdg.de.

Contents
• 6 large (1168mm x 820mm) maps
• 4800 full colour counters
• 1 Rules book
• 1 Scenarios book
• Combat Charts
• 2 x 10-sided dice

In AD HOP both players try to move their pawns form one edge of the board to the opposite edge. To reach their goal, they have to move boats on the river by tactical playing movement-tokens. 
A further element in the game is driftwood that can be placed in order to frustrate your oppenents plans (a mechanic well known form Quoridor)

The Company has colonised the planet LV-426. Contact with the "Shake and bake" colony is lost. The Company sends a team of Colonial Marines, with Ripley as "Advisor", to find out what has happened at Hadley's Hope.

Aliens: This Time it's War is an unauthorised, non-profit and non-collectable card game set within the boundaries of the hugely influential 1986 sci-fi film, Aliens.

Consisting of two balanced 60-card decks, the game pits two players against each other in a life or death struggle. One player takes the role of the Colonial Marines, and his opponent assumes control of the hordes of deadly xenomorphs.

At their disposal, the Colonial Marines - very tough hombres - have a roster of high-tech, state-of-the-art weaponry.

The Alien player's objective is to eliminate all the Marines, before they escape the planet and "Nuke the entire site from orbit."

The game has an asymmetrical design, with both decks featuring different cards and abilities. Aliens: This Time it's War is played using a 5-column system, representing consecutive melees. Gameplay is quick and bloodthirsty with Marines butchered frequently, and aliens destroyed by the well-placed use of cards.

Numerous tricky decisions must be made throughout. For instance, the Colonial Marine player could choose to deploy the Powerloader during the Reactor Chamber battle, but the resources that this would require make it a very risky, but rewarding, play. Similarly, the Alien player can deploy the Alien Queen at any time during the conflict - she's free to play aboard the Sulaco, but hugely expensive if used during the APC Withdrawal, for instance.

Primarily a combat-driven card game, each player must manage his deck of cards effectively to win. In addition to simple, unique abilities, each card also has two values: power and cost. No icons are used.

Aliens: This Time it's War can trace its parentage back to San Juan, Magic: The Gathering, Battle Line, BattleTech CCG, and Iliad.

Victory Conditions:


 The Colonial Marine player wins if she manages to "Nuke the entire site from orbit".
 The Colonial Marine player wins if she reaches and survives the Sulaco Loading Bay battle.
 The Alien player wins if Ripley and all the Colonial Marines are either killed or cocooned.

item.description:
12 Men on the Field:Deluxe Edition lets you be the owner of a professional football franchise. It is based on football as it is played in the United States. You follow your team through a 14 week season and, with good play calling and some luck, into the playoffs.

The Zeppelin Edition lets you watch the game like a true fan. Cheer for the touchdown, complain about the bad penalty calls, berate your coach for going for it on 4th and 25 yards to go...

The Sideline Edition lets you call the plays. Will you run on 1st and 10? Pass? Mix it up a little to keep your opponent’s defense guessing? That 4th and 25 isn’t such a no brainer when you are behind with two minutes left to play. The Sideline Edition is an add-on to the Zeppelin Edition.

Two great ways to play American Football.

Bai is played on a board with 9x10 squares.
Players place markers (paths) on a square to build a path or move one of their pawns on a path. Used paths are removed. If there are too many paths in one area, they are all removed. If a player cannot move any more, he loses the game.

User Summary: A card game where players try to collect most valuable suggestions to save energy in different categories.

There are five categories: Kühlen (refrigerating), Waschen (washing), Unterhaltung/Information (entertainment/information electronics), Heizen (heating) and Beleuchtung (light). For each category there are six suggestion/hint cards ranging from 3 to 6 points representing saving suggestions.

A stack is built from these hint cards and several Kurzschluss (black out / power surge) cards. Players take turns. The active player reveals cards from the stack one by one. At any time he can stop and take the highest valued cards on his hand the rest of the cards is place face up in front of the player and it is the next player's turn. If a Kurzschluss shows up all cards of that turn are lost and placed face down under the stack together with the Kurzschluss. Instead of revealing new cards the active player may exchange a card from his hand with a higher valued cards from the open cards of the same category.

Round ends when a player collects one hint from each category. If the points add up to 27 and more round ends instantly. All other players lose a live represented by two Stecker (plug) cards.
If score is below 27 the sum is kept secret and all other players get another turn to get more points. Then all players tally their points. The player(s) with the lowest score lose a live.

All cards are shuffled and a new round begins. Game ends when only one player is left.

Der 7. Zwerg (The 7th dwarf) is an abstract capturing game played on a board with 35 squares arranged in a spiral two squares wide.
If you jump over a dwarf, this one is removed from the game and replaced by one of yours. 
The player how has all 7 of his dwarfes in play / removed all opponents dawarfs wins the game.

"This is a XXI century society game, a board game of the 2nd generation to play with family or friends of all ages (from 8 years).

This is a race through "CASAS DO BENFICA DE PORTUGAL", covering a virtual distance of approximately 2,500 kms, with departure and arrival at the Stadium of Light in Lisbon. Participants in the game - 2-6 - position in the area of departure - LISBON, each participant sequentially turn the ROULETTE wheel and obey the instructions, you can receive positive kms (Pin progresses), negative kms (Pin backs), crossings of motorways, HELI-TRANSPORT, LETTERS SPECIAL BONUS...

WINS THE MATCH who first returns to the Stadium of Light - LISBON. "

From publishers web site

A trick-taking game played with traditional playing cards.

When you win a hand, the winning card is discarded and the rest of the cards in the trick go into your hand. The round ends when one player runs out of cards.

Score is kept after each hand for every card left in that player's hand.

The player with the most points after 3 rounds wins.

Renault F1 Team
The official licensed Board Game
Welcome to the exhilarating world of Fornmula 1 racing!
The circuits are divided into spaces and the players advance their cars using speed cards. Each card indicates how many spaces a car has to move. Excessive speed, braking or cornering at high speed may reduce the efficiency of your car up to the point where it breaks down and you have to retire.

Tha game contains one mounted board with two circuits (Montecarlo and Sakhir), 20 colored plastic cars, 20 driver cards, 90 speed cards, 4 dice, a timer (used to measure the length of pit stops in the advanced rules version) and 5 rules booklets (one per language)

item.description:
Loop is a semi-cooperative abstract strategy game for up to six players or teams.

Play involves laying cards to build colored loops, with longer loops worth more points at the end of the game. Players accrue victory points for loops of certain colors, so building a red loop, for example, will gain either single, double, or no points for each player.

Each player has their own hidden agenda - even though they will naturally work together to build a loop, each of their six Victory condition cards is different, awarding different multipliers for each color. Each loop you help to build will gain points for other players too, so some network blocking/redirecting strategy will be needed to make sure you come out on top.

Suggestions are included for team play and for family gaming.

Uh-Oh Mountain is a roll & move game that has players depicting snow skiers racing down a mountain. Each player will roll two dice to move and if they land an Uh-Oh space (about 1/3 of the space) they draw an Uh-Oh card which will transport them to another space on the board (either being a reward or a punishment.

This game appears to be somewhat similar to Wheeler Dealer, which offers differently branded versions of the game through different community organizations, typically the Chamber of Commerce of that city. MARINES, THE GAME, appears to be a roll and move game, with property, two event decks, and a victory condition based on having the most cash.

Der Weg des Königs (The King´s Path) is played on a Board of 4x10 rectangles. 
The aim of the game is to get your king safe to the oppisite side of the board or to capture the opponents king with one of your henchman. The king does not move across the vacant land, so you fave to develop ractangels to pathes first. For this, you control a third kind of character, an architect.

There are 65 cards in five colors and with five symbols, numbered 1 to 13. At the start of the game, the players decide whether they will search for symbols or for colors. The task then is to locate all cards with that color/symbol in the right order.

The cards are dealt so that in front of each player, there are two stacks. As soon as the game starts, each player grabs one (any!) stack of cards and looks through it, trying to find the first card he/she needs. When successful, he/she puts the card face-down in front of him/her. Whether successful or not, the rest of the stack is put back to its position. The player then grabs another stack and proceeds. If the players can remember the contents of all the stacks, it's easier for them to find the cards they need later.

The first player to complete his/her stack correctly is the winner. If the fastest player is making a mistake, the player with most correct cards is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name.value: Remember Limerick! The War of the Two Kings: Ireland, 1689-1691

item.description:
from the Red Sash Games website:

Remember Limerick! (RL!) is the seventh volume of Red Sash Games' Lace Wars series, and opens a new subject, the Nine Years War, sometimes called the War of the League of Augsburg, Toward the end of the 17th Century, at a time when Europe is consumed by war, the powerful Catholic dynasty of the Habsburgs, and the Pope, have formed an unnatural league with the Protestant states of northern Germany, and with the Prince of Orange, de facto ruler of the Netherlands, against their coreligionists, the French. They oppose the overweening ambitions of the Sun King, Louis XIV. To augment the strength of the League, William, Prince of Orange, has taken advantage of popular dissatisfaction with his father-in-law, King James II, to engineer an armed coup and take over the government of England. This will help fill the coffers of the League and ensure that England does not ally with France.

But the English throne brings with it the governance of Scotland and of Ireland. While some in these countries welcome the Glorious Revolution, many do not. Especially is this so in Ireland, where a small Protestant minority lords it over a helot population of Irish and Anglo-Irish Catholics - an Ascendancy secured only a generation before by the swords of Oliver Cromwell's men and still maintained by force of arms and by force of English Law. In the last years of King James' rule, his Deputy, Richard Talbot, Earl of Tyrconnel, has worked hard to overturn this Cromwellian Settlement, stuffing the Administration and the Army with Catholics. The Protestants are afraid.

King James, abandoned by many that he trusted, including his own family, suffers a nervous breakdown and leaves England for France, determined to devote the rest of his life to religious pursuits. But his cousin, King Louis, points to Ireland as a place where a fallen monarch may retrieve his fortunes. Tyrconnel and the new Irish Army, and a picked brigade of veteran French, will enable James to drive his son-in-law from the British Isles - and incidentally, force Dutch Billy to withdraw much of his army from the Low Countries, where the French hope to gain much in the next few campaigns. The last Irish "rebellion" lasted eleven years....

Morphisto is a capturing game played on a board of 9x8 squares.
It is played with 4 kinds of meeples.

Morphisto: A shape-shifter whose movement range is indicated by rings he wears, but looses after the movement.
Cangoo: The most agile one.
Scarab: Comparable with pawns
Palazzo: Comparable to the general in Xiang Qi

The aim of the game is not to capture the opponents palazzo, but to immobilize him.

Mutaris is a connection game played with 77 2-coloured balls on a square 9x9 without the 4 areas in the corners.
Each player has to build roads of balls in his colour form one edge to the opposite edge by rotating 14 balls each turn. 
Plyers score points for each road they build.

Rififi is a capturing game played on a square 7x7 without the corner fields. In field in the middle of a board i a fountain you can fall in, similar to the holes known from in Arima.
Each player contriles 8 simmilar fighters.
The aim of the game is to knock out all opponents either by pulling them into the fountain or by attacking them where they are. There are some special movement rules.
You can not move away from an opponent.
You can stumble over another fighters lying on the ground.
Attacked fighters reach diffent states. They loos thier hat, than they fall, but can stand up and fially they are knocked out.

Nile: the Dice Game is based on the card game Nile/

In Nile: the Dice Game, players take on the role of farmers in ancient Egypt. There are five resources that are farmed by all players throughout the game. Players collectively keep track of plagues which eventually end the game. Aside from the seven resource dice, there are three speculation dice which allow players to increase the amount of dice they roll each turn and to modify the results of their dice. Scoring is done as in Nile the card game where your score is equal to the resource of which you have the least.

One major difference in Nile: the Dice Game from the original card game is the solo option. In a solo game you are challenging an invisible player whose score increases as you go.

Nile: the Dice Game is fast (10 - 20 minutes), easy to learn, easy to setup and put away, and best of all... FREE!! (at least for now).

A card game published on thegamecrafter.com that bears a fairly strong resemblance to Uno.

You start the game with seven cards. The first player to get rid of their hand wins. On your turn, you can play a card matching the color of the face up card or a special card. If you do neither, you draw a card. The card can be immediately played. Special cards include Skip, which skip the next player's turn, rainbows, which can be played after any color and cause the next player to draw a number of cards, power animals, which can be played on any color and allow the player to play all cards in their hand of that animal, and bug cards, which require the next player to play a bug spray card or draw a card, continuing until a bug spray is played.

From TheGamecrafter.com:

"Be the first to play all the kitties, doggies, mousies, and bunnies from your hand. Power animals will help you out, but watch out for the dreaded Bug or you'll need to find some Bug Spray!

A fast-playing card game for 2-6 players. We play it with kids ages 4 and up. By Colleen and Matt Leacock."

Game contents: 
47 cards
Rules document

Welcome, fellow malpractitioner! Take on the role of an unscrupulous, incompetent quack doctor treating patients with whatever medicines or surgeries happen to be available that day. Sure, they may not “help,” but they sure are lucrative! Whoever ends the game with the most money wins. Just be careful not to kill too many patients, or an angry mob will come after you!

Designed by an M.D., tested by gamers, and illustrated by the amazing Len Peralta!

Each doctor (player) draws patients and treatments at random. You have to play a number of treatments determined by die roll. You may not cure them, but you may hope to make money without “adverse outcomes!” If they survive, they pay. If they die, you accumulate infamy – and too much of that will end your practice… permanently. If you are cunning, you may get rich enough to flee to Switzerland before people catch on that you are a QUACK!

Includes 140 full-color cards, each with unique illustrations. You’ll also need paper, pencil and one six-sided die to play (not included).

name.value: Omega the End Times Board Game

item.description:
Published by Forerunner Publishing a division of Friends of the Bridegroom, Inc, Omega the End Times Board Game is a game of knowledge (trivia question and answer) based on biblical eschatology. Trivia questions are based on knowledge of certain books of the New King James bible, such as Daniel, Matthew, and the Book of Revelation.

The board contains six colored tracks that extend from left to right along the rectangular game board. Each colored track corresponds to six colored playing pieces. Each player selects a colored playing piece and places it on the track.

On each turn, the player gets an opportunity to answer a trivia card question. If answered correctly, the player moves forward along the track and they get to draw special "oil" or "crown" cards that count for victory points at game end. The tracks have certain phases which represent passage of time. For example, the left most track section is the present, the middle of the track corresponds to the "tribulation period", the end of the track corresponds to the "millennium", etc.. The first player to reach a time-based stage causes all other players to immediately move forward to that stage.

In order to win the game, a player must answer questions correctly allowing them changes to collect oil and crown cards that are worth points. When a player reaches the final stage of the track, all players get one more turn. Then card-points are added up to determine a winner.

It is an educational game focused on the escatolagical teachings of Friends of the Bridegroom, Inc, AKA International House of Prayer, located in Kansas City.

(From the game box)

Top Gear: The Ultimate Car Challenge Board Game

It's just like on the telly... but in a box.

Prove you're the ultimate Top Gear fan and win. How hard can that be?

- Know Jezza, James and Richard better than their mums
- Know what's cool, sub-zero, and what's in the fridge
- Beat the Stig's Power Laps
- Know that caravans are for playing conkers with... and never, ever for taking a holiday in
- And always, always drive faster than Captain Slow.

Object of the Game
Collect the points that make up your ultimate car and be the first player to land on or pass the Finish space to win the game.

Contents:
- Game Board
- Player Guide
- 12 Ultimate Car Cards
- 43 Hazard Cards
- 165 Question Cards
- Score Pad
- 4 Player Movers
- Die

Instruction manual introduction:

Here's a new "portable" table tennis game whose lively action folks of all ages enjoy, from the five-year-olds up to the adults in the family! It has the came [sic] court and the same scoring as table tennis, but you "snap the Wink" instead of hitting the ball. The Wink-on-a-String never gets lost, so WINK TENNIS can be played anywhere, even on trips or when sick-a-bed, etc. Two players can play Singles; or 4 players can play Doubles.

Black Jack, the pirates has been retired. He was always a lonely wolf. With his last action he tricked his fellow partners. The treasures that was robbed together, he melted in one, broke it to 3 parts and burried them separately. The pirates started to search the parts...Will they find them? Take part in this treasure hunt and find all the 3 parts to win.

From the back of the board game

In this game you are controlling one of the 4 pirates who is searching for the treasure.
You start with 9 markers and 3 mission cards. The game board has got a 7 * 10 matrix. Every row and coloumn has got a colored skull symbol (4 player colours and a black one) These skulls are important:
1. The player needs to go one of the cross point of his/her colour. In the board there is only 2 spots like that.
In this spot he/she may check one of the 3 treasure cards that was received at the start of the game..
2. The black skulls cross points. In there you have to draw a card. These could be:
a, Key card --> needed for the treasure (3 for the 3 pieces of the treasure)
b, A steeringwheel--> you will be on turn again
c, A storm-->you will miss 1 turn
d, A skull-->gather 4 and your game is over.

If you know where the part of the treasure is hidden, you need to go there and place 4 marker in the crosspoints that surronded the location. You can not place a marer if someone else has got there a marker. You need to keep in secret what is your mission!

The winner is who can collect the 3 parts of the treasure first.

This game needs strategy, luck too.

item.description:
A fan-made card game based on the characters from Project Shrine Maiden (Touhou Project). A two-player versus card game in the style of Magic: the Gathering, as the players play characters, spells and interrupts on each other, trying to bring the opponent's life points down to zero.

Translated box back:
Easy to grasp, yet deep! A new card game using the characters!

A new type of card game where the player uses cards depicting all the lovable characters from Project Shrine Maiden, builds his own deck and gets to battle with it.

Catonka is a combination of a tile placement and capturing game.
First, players place rectangles and squares of different size on the board and place their armies with different strength on them. After all fields and armies are placed, the capturing begins. An army can only move on an adjacent filed with a weaker unit on it, which than is captured. After no more capture is possible (units can't move without capturing), the player with the largest army leftover wins.

name.value: Kiumbove aneb Tajuplny balik z Afriky

item.description:
It is not just a board game, the packaging consist of a comics and it reaches beyond the classical board games - it is a helping hand for people in Africa. They make each and every one of the Kiumbi characters, which are in the game.
The game itself is mainly focused on children as it the whole design. It contains five characters, that are amazingly designed and handcrafted. They "sleep" on one side of the box in a little space with holes, so they can breathe.
It plays quickly. The game board is round, with five pathways to centre and nine points, that leads to victory. On start of each pathway you put one Kiumbi character and secretly choose one of them, who you will support.
Each player gets three cards with symbol, that matches one game character. When you play this card, that character moves one space to the center. But there are influences between characters - water tames fire and so on, so when you play fire, fire character moves one space forward, but another two characters move too - one forward and one backward. These influences are nicely shown on the board.
When first of kiumbis reaches the centre the game ends and who has supported this character wins. Game can also end sooner, when somebody guesses another players secret favorit.

It's a children racing game. 
Players throw with 2 dices, one normal with numbers from 1 to 6, but the other one is for the careful ones and it contains only numbers 1 and 2, three of each. Player can throw with both dices or only one of his/her choice.
Players move around the board and in every turn they have to stop once, otherwise their car got out of control and they have to wait for one turn.
When two players end up in one spot, they battle for the leading place with dice.
